				<form class="tight" method="post" action="/script/Surveys/Vote.aspx?srvid=2389" name="SurveyForm" onsubmit="return Submit();">
<input type="hidden" name="ID" id="ID" value="2389">
<input type="hidden" name="buttonPressed" id="buttonPressed" value="void" /><input type="hidden" name="answersResults" id="answersResults" value="" />
<div class="survey brief">
<div class="heading"><img src="/images/poll24.png" style="width:25px;height:24px"> Straw Poll</div><div class="header">
AI can drive a car and write a novel. What's the value a software developer brings that AI can't?<div class="description">Are we slowly being replaced and haven't yet noticed, or will AI always be merely a tool that us Skilled Professionals wield to make a better world?</div>
</div>
<div class="content">
<table class="question" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<tr valign="top"><td width="16px"><input id="SE_4348_33131" name="SE_4348_33131" type="checkbox"></td><td><label for="SE_4348_33131">We developers understand humans, and so can cater to their illogical needs</label></td></tr>
<tr valign="top"><td width="16px"><input id="SE_4348_33132" name="SE_4348_33132" type="checkbox"></td><td><label for="SE_4348_33132">AI can only mimic what's been done, but can't <i>truly</i> innovate</label></td></tr>
<tr valign="top"><td width="16px"><input id="SE_4348_33133" name="SE_4348_33133" type="checkbox"></td><td><label for="SE_4348_33133">AI can never make something fun</label></td></tr>
<tr valign="top"><td width="16px"><input id="SE_4348_33134" name="SE_4348_33134" type="checkbox"></td><td><label for="SE_4348_33134">AI are terrible at team building exercises</label></td></tr>
<tr valign="top"><td width="16px"><input id="SE_4348_33135" name="SE_4348_33135" type="checkbox"></td><td><label for="SE_4348_33135">Us developers keep entire legions of QA testers employed. An AI can't do that.</label></td></tr>
<tr valign="top"><td width="16px"><input id="SE_4348_33136" name="SE_4348_33136" type="checkbox"></td><td><label for="SE_4348_33136">An AI could never explain to its manager why it did something</label></td></tr>
<tr valign="top"><td width="16px"><input id="SE_4348_33137" name="SE_4348_33137" type="checkbox"></td><td><label for="SE_4348_33137">AI systems are terrible at understanding what's <i>not</i> being said by your manager</label></td></tr>
<tr valign="top"><td width="16px"><input id="SE_4348_33138" name="SE_4348_33138" type="checkbox"></td><td><label for="SE_4348_33138">Nothing. Given time, AI will render us superfluous. We're doomed.</label></td></tr>
</table>
<div class="vote-bar small-text">
<input class="button" type="submit" value="Vote" onclick="return Submit();">

</div>

var sessionCountState = {
                lastChanged : new Date(),
                previous : 0,
                current : 0
            };

            function updateSessionCountData() {
                $.ajax({
                    url: '/script/Membership/webservices/MemberServices.aspx/GetCurrentSessionCountData',
                    cache: false,
                    type: 'POST',
                    contentType: 'application/json'
                })
                .done(function (data) {
                    var sessionCount = data.d.SessionCount;
                    var rampCount = 15000;

                    if (sessionCount != sessionCountState.current)
                    {
                        sessionCountState.lastChanged = new Date();
                        sessionCountState.previous    = sessionCountState.current;
                        sessionCountState.current     = sessionCount;
                        if (sessionCountState.previous != 0) {
                            rampCount = 60000;
                        }
                        else {
                            sessionCountState.previous = sessionCount;
                        }
                    }
                    
                    var valueToReturn = sessionCountState.previous
                                      + ((sessionCountState.current - sessionCountState.previous) 
                                         * Math.min(new Date() - sessionCountState.lastChanged, rampCount)) / rampCount;

                    var noise = Math.random() * 30 - 15;
                    
                    valueToReturn = Math.round(valueToReturn + noise);

                    $('#SessionCount').html(valueToReturn.toString().replace(/\B(?=(?:\d{3})+(?!\d))/g, ','));
                });
            }

var ctl00_MC_MarketingStats_PageViews_loadState =
{
    previousSeries : null,
    currentSeries  : null,
    nextRefresh    : new Date(),
    lastRefresh    : null
};

function ctl00_MC_MarketingStats_PageViews_loadData()
{
    var state = ctl00_MC_MarketingStats_PageViews_loadState;

    var deferred = new $.Deferred();

    if (500 === 0  ||
        state.previousSeries == null ||
        state.currentSeries == null  ||
        new Date() >= state.nextRefresh) {

        state.lastRefresh = state.nextRefresh;
        state.nextRefresh = new Date();
        state.nextRefresh.setSeconds(state.nextRefresh.getSeconds() + 10);

        $.ajax({
            url:         '/script/Common/Webservices/CommonServices.aspx/GetPageViewsTimeSeriesData',
            data:        '{"fillGraph":true,"chartType":1}',
            cache:       false,
            type:        'POST',
            dataType:    'text', // or 'json' if we're getting data from JSON
            contentType: 'application/json'
        })
        .done(function(data) {
            var series = JSON.parse(JSON.parse(data).d); // if we're getting data from Text

            // var series = data.d;           // if we're getting data from JSON

            if (!series || !series[0]) {
                seriesToReturn = state.currentSeries;
            }
            else
            {
                // HACK: This is for the homepage pageview bargraph. As we get new data we want to
                //       animate the right-most bar (but only that bar). So we check to see if it
                //       needs an update. If not, don't do anything
                var seriesToReturn;
                if (state.currentSeries != null && state.currentSeries[0] != null && state.currentSeries[0].data != null) {
                    // check if new time
                    if (state.currentSeries[0].data[0][0] !== series[0].data[0][0]) {
                        // only want to 'animate' the rightmost bar.
                        state.currentSeries = JSON.parse(JSON.stringify(series));
                        for (var i = 0; i < state.currentSeries.length; i++) {
                            state.currentSeries[i].data[0][1] = 0;
                        }
                    }
                    seriesToReturn = state.currentSeries;
                }
                else
                    seriesToReturn = series;

                state.previousSeries = state.currentSeries;
                state.currentSeries  = series;
            }

            deferred.resolve(seriesToReturn);
        })
        .fail(function(jqXHR, textStatus, errorThrown) {
            deferred.reject();
            console.log('Error: ' + jqXHR.responseText);
        });

    } else {

        var newSeries = JSON.parse(JSON.stringify(state.previousSeries));

        var date = new Date();
        var millisecondsSince = (new Date() - state.lastRefresh);

        for (var seriesIndex = 0; seriesIndex < state.currentSeries.length; seriesIndex++) {
            var series = state.currentSeries[seriesIndex];
            var interumData = new Array();
            for (var i = 0; i < series.data.length; i++) {
                var prevValue = state.previousSeries[seriesIndex].data[i];
                var change   = series.data[i][1] - prevValue[1];
                var newValue = prevValue[1] + ((change * millisecondsSince )/ 10000);
                interumData.push([ series.data[i][0], newValue ]);
            }

            newSeries[seriesIndex].data = interumData;
        }

        deferred.resolve(newSeries);
    }

    return deferred;
}

	function flotter_ctl00_MC_MarketingStats_PageViews_StatsGraph() {
	
	    var self = this;
	
	    this.flot = new flotWrapper();
	    var loading = false;
	
	    var options = {
	        series:    { curvedLines: { active: true }, stack: false },
	        crosshair: {  },
	
	        xaxis:     { mode: 'time', timezone: 'browser', timeformat: '', tickSize: [5, 'minute']},
	
	        yaxes:     [
	                     { position: "left",  min:  0, tickFormatter: self.flot.numberWithCommas, tickDecimals:0 /* First shared y axis on left */  },
	                     { position: "right", min:  0, tickFormatter: self.flot.numberWithCommas, tickDecimals:0 /* First shared y axis on right */ },
	
	                   ],
	        selection: { mode: 'x' },
	        grid:      {
	                      show          : true,
	                      hoverable     : false,  // important! self.flot.tooltip requires this
	                      borderWidth   : 1,
	                      autoHighlight : !false, // for vertical line tooltip
	                      markings      : null,
	                      clickable     : false
	                   },
	        legend:    {
	                      show              : false,
	                      noColumns         : 1,
	                      position          : 'nw',
	                      backgroundOpacity : 0.6,
	                      labelFormatter    : function(label, series) {
	                          if (series.showLatestValueInLegend) {
	                             var latest = self.getLastValueInRange(series);
	                             return '<span class="tiny-text">' + label + ' (' + latest + ')</span>'
	                          }
	                          else if (series.showTotalInLabel) {
	                             var total = self.getTotalInRange(series);
	                             return '<span class="tiny-text">' + label + ' (' + total + ')</span>'
	                          }
	
	                          return '<span class="tiny-text">' + label + '</span>';
	                      }
	                                   },
	        tooltip:   {
	                      show              : !false,
	                      content           : "%s: %y.0 at %x",
	                      xDateFormat       : "%d-%m-%Y %H:%M",
	                      showValuesOnHover : false
	                   }
	    };
	
	    this.paused = false;
	    this.getTotalInRange = function (series) {
	        return self.flot.numberWithCommas(self.flot.getTotalInRange(series));
	    };
	    this.getLastValueInRange = function (series) {
	        return self.flot.numberWithCommas(self.flot.getLastValueInRange(series));
	    };
	    this.plotGraph = function (showSpinner) {
	    if (this.paused) return;
	    if (loading) return; loading = true;
	    var opts = { length:17, width:5, radius:12, trail:50, shadow:false, color:'#666' };
	    var plotDiv = $('#ctl00_MC_MarketingStats_PageViews_StatsGraph_ChartArea');
	    plotDiv.css({ position: 'relative'});
	    plotDiv.find('.no-data').remove();
	    var spinner = showSpinner ? new Spinner(opts).spin(plotDiv[0]) : null;
	    $.when(ctl00_MC_MarketingStats_PageViews_loadData()).then(function(series) {
	        var hasRAxis = false;
	        if (spinner) spinner.stop();
	        if (series && series.length) {
	            self.flot.PlotData(options, series, 'ctl00_MC_MarketingStats_PageViews_StatsGraph_ChartArea');
	            for (var s = 0; s < series.length; s++) if (series[s].yaxis > 1) { hasRAxis = true; break; }
	        } else { 
	            plotDiv.html('<div class="no-data" style="color:#999;position:absolute;top:49%;left:46%">No data</div>');
	        }
	        loading = false;
	    }, function() {
	        if (spinner) spinner.stop(); loading = false;
	        plotDiv.html('<div class="no-data" style="color:#999;position:absolute;top:49%;left:46%">No data</div>');
	        loading = false;
	    });
	        return false;
	    }
	}

<div class="survey brief">
<div class="heading"><img src="/images/poll24.png" style="width:25px;height:24px"> Straw Poll</div><div class="header">
AI can drive a car and write a novel. What's the value a software developer brings that AI can't?<div class="description">Are we slowly being replaced and haven't yet noticed, or will AI always be merely a tool that us Skilled Professionals wield to make a better world?</div>
</div>
<div class="content">
<table class="question" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<tr valign="top"><td width="16px"><input id="SE_4348_33131" name="SE_4348_33131" type="checkbox"></td><td><label for="SE_4348_33131">We developers understand humans, and so can cater to their illogical needs</label></td></tr>
<tr valign="top"><td width="16px"><input id="SE_4348_33132" name="SE_4348_33132" type="checkbox"></td><td><label for="SE_4348_33132">AI can only mimic what's been done, but can't <i>truly</i> innovate</label></td></tr>
<tr valign="top"><td width="16px"><input id="SE_4348_33133" name="SE_4348_33133" type="checkbox"></td><td><label for="SE_4348_33133">AI can never make something fun</label></td></tr>
<tr valign="top"><td width="16px"><input id="SE_4348_33134" name="SE_4348_33134" type="checkbox"></td><td><label for="SE_4348_33134">AI are terrible at team building exercises</label></td></tr>
<tr valign="top"><td width="16px"><input id="SE_4348_33135" name="SE_4348_33135" type="checkbox"></td><td><label for="SE_4348_33135">Us developers keep entire legions of QA testers employed. An AI can't do that.</label></td></tr>
<tr valign="top"><td width="16px"><input id="SE_4348_33136" name="SE_4348_33136" type="checkbox"></td><td><label for="SE_4348_33136">An AI could never explain to its manager why it did something</label></td></tr>
<tr valign="top"><td width="16px"><input id="SE_4348_33137" name="SE_4348_33137" type="checkbox"></td><td><label for="SE_4348_33137">AI systems are terrible at understanding what's <i>not</i> being said by your manager</label></td></tr>
<tr valign="top"><td width="16px"><input id="SE_4348_33138" name="SE_4348_33138" type="checkbox"></td><td><label for="SE_4348_33138">Nothing. Given time, AI will render us superfluous. We're doomed.</label></td></tr>
</table>

var sessionCountState = {
                lastChanged : new Date(),
                previous : 0,
                current : 0
            };

            function updateSessionCountData() {
                $.ajax({
                    url: '/script/Membership/webservices/MemberServices.aspx/GetCurrentSessionCountData',
                    cache: false,
                    type: 'POST',
                    contentType: 'application/json'
                })
                .done(function (data) {
                    var sessionCount = data.d.SessionCount;
                    var rampCount = 15000;

                    if (sessionCount != sessionCountState.current)
                    {
                        sessionCountState.lastChanged = new Date();
                        sessionCountState.previous    = sessionCountState.current;
                        sessionCountState.current     = sessionCount;
                        if (sessionCountState.previous != 0) {
                            rampCount = 60000;
                        }
                        else {
                            sessionCountState.previous = sessionCount;
                        }
                    }
                    
                    var valueToReturn = sessionCountState.previous
                                      + ((sessionCountState.current - sessionCountState.previous) 
                                         * Math.min(new Date() - sessionCountState.lastChanged, rampCount)) / rampCount;

                    var noise = Math.random() * 30 - 15;
                    
                    valueToReturn = Math.round(valueToReturn + noise);

                    $('#SessionCount').html(valueToReturn.toString().replace(/\B(?=(?:\d{3})+(?!\d))/g, ','));
                });
            }

    var state = ctl00_MC_MarketingStats_PageViews_loadState;

    var deferred = new $.Deferred();

    if (500 === 0  ||
        state.previousSeries == null ||
        state.currentSeries == null  ||
        new Date() >= state.nextRefresh) {

        state.lastRefresh = state.nextRefresh;
        state.nextRefresh = new Date();
        state.nextRefresh.setSeconds(state.nextRefresh.getSeconds() + 10);

        $.ajax({
            url:         '/script/Common/Webservices/CommonServices.aspx/GetPageViewsTimeSeriesData',
            data:        '{"fillGraph":true,"chartType":1}',
            cache:       false,
            type:        'POST',
            dataType:    'text', // or 'json' if we're getting data from JSON
            contentType: 'application/json'
        })
        .done(function(data) {
            var series = JSON.parse(JSON.parse(data).d); // if we're getting data from Text

            // var series = data.d;           // if we're getting data from JSON

            if (!series || !series[0]) {
                seriesToReturn = state.currentSeries;
            }
            else
            {
                // HACK: This is for the homepage pageview bargraph. As we get new data we want to
                //       animate the right-most bar (but only that bar). So we check to see if it
                //       needs an update. If not, don't do anything
                var seriesToReturn;
                if (state.currentSeries != null && state.currentSeries[0] != null && state.currentSeries[0].data != null) {
                    // check if new time
                    if (state.currentSeries[0].data[0][0] !== series[0].data[0][0]) {
                        // only want to 'animate' the rightmost bar.
                        state.currentSeries = JSON.parse(JSON.stringify(series));
                        for (var i = 0; i < state.currentSeries.length; i++) {
                            state.currentSeries[i].data[0][1] = 0;
                        }
                    }
                    seriesToReturn = state.currentSeries;
                }
                else
                    seriesToReturn = series;

                state.previousSeries = state.currentSeries;
                state.currentSeries  = series;
            }

            deferred.resolve(seriesToReturn);
        })
        .fail(function(jqXHR, textStatus, errorThrown) {
            deferred.reject();
            console.log('Error: ' + jqXHR.responseText);
        });

    } else {

        var newSeries = JSON.parse(JSON.stringify(state.previousSeries));

        var date = new Date();
        var millisecondsSince = (new Date() - state.lastRefresh);

        for (var seriesIndex = 0; seriesIndex < state.currentSeries.length; seriesIndex++) {
            var series = state.currentSeries[seriesIndex];
            var interumData = new Array();
            for (var i = 0; i < series.data.length; i++) {
                var prevValue = state.previousSeries[seriesIndex].data[i];
                var change   = series.data[i][1] - prevValue[1];
                var newValue = prevValue[1] + ((change * millisecondsSince )/ 10000);
                interumData.push([ series.data[i][0], newValue ]);
            }

            newSeries[seriesIndex].data = interumData;
        }

        deferred.resolve(newSeries);
    }

    return deferred;
}

var bookmark_medium_false_false_ = null;
</script>

	function flotter_ctl00_MC_MarketingStats_PageViews_StatsGraph() {
	
	    var self = this;
	
	    this.flot = new flotWrapper();
	    var loading = false;
	
	    var options = {
	        series:    { curvedLines: { active: true }, stack: false },
	        crosshair: {  },
	
	        xaxis:     { mode: 'time', timezone: 'browser', timeformat: '', tickSize: [5, 'minute']},
	
	        yaxes:     [
	                     { position: "left",  min:  0, tickFormatter: self.flot.numberWithCommas, tickDecimals:0 /* First shared y axis on left */  },
	                     { position: "right", min:  0, tickFormatter: self.flot.numberWithCommas, tickDecimals:0 /* First shared y axis on right */ },
	
	                   ],
	        selection: { mode: 'x' },
	        grid:      {
	                      show          : true,
	                      hoverable     : false,  // important! self.flot.tooltip requires this
	                      borderWidth   : 1,
	                      autoHighlight : !false, // for vertical line tooltip
	                      markings      : null,
	                      clickable     : false
	                   },
	        legend:    {
	                      show              : false,
	                      noColumns         : 1,
	                      position          : 'nw',
	                      backgroundOpacity : 0.6,
	                      labelFormatter    : function(label, series) {
	                          if (series.showLatestValueInLegend) {
	                             var latest = self.getLastValueInRange(series);
	                             return '<span class="tiny-text">' + label + ' (' + latest + ')</span>'
	                          }
	                          else if (series.showTotalInLabel) {
	                             var total = self.getTotalInRange(series);
	                             return '<span class="tiny-text">' + label + ' (' + total + ')</span>'
	                          }
	
	                          return '<span class="tiny-text">' + label + '</span>';
	                      }
	                                   },
	        tooltip:   {
	                      show              : !false,
	                      content           : "%s: %y.0 at %x",
	                      xDateFormat       : "%d-%m-%Y %H:%M",
	                      showValuesOnHover : false
	                   }
	    };
	
	    this.paused = false;
	    this.getTotalInRange = function (series) {
	        return self.flot.numberWithCommas(self.flot.getTotalInRange(series));
	    };
	    this.getLastValueInRange = function (series) {
	        return self.flot.numberWithCommas(self.flot.getLastValueInRange(series));
	    };
	    this.plotGraph = function (showSpinner) {
	    if (this.paused) return;
	    if (loading) return; loading = true;
	    var opts = { length:17, width:5, radius:12, trail:50, shadow:false, color:'#666' };
	    var plotDiv = $('#ctl00_MC_MarketingStats_PageViews_StatsGraph_ChartArea');
	    plotDiv.css({ position: 'relative'});
	    plotDiv.find('.no-data').remove();
	    var spinner = showSpinner ? new Spinner(opts).spin(plotDiv[0]) : null;
	    $.when(ctl00_MC_MarketingStats_PageViews_loadData()).then(function(series) {
	        var hasRAxis = false;
	        if (spinner) spinner.stop();
	        if (series && series.length) {
	            self.flot.PlotData(options, series, 'ctl00_MC_MarketingStats_PageViews_StatsGraph_ChartArea');
	            for (var s = 0; s < series.length; s++) if (series[s].yaxis > 1) { hasRAxis = true; break; }
	        } else { 
	            plotDiv.html('<div class="no-data" style="color:#999;position:absolute;top:49%;left:46%">No data</div>');
	        }
	        loading = false;
	    }, function() {
	        if (spinner) spinner.stop(); loading = false;
	        plotDiv.html('<div class="no-data" style="color:#999;position:absolute;top:49%;left:46%">No data</div>');
	        loading = false;
	    });
	        return false;
	    }
	}

                        <div id="ctl00_DescriptionSpot" class="summary">From a small set of tools to a much larger ecosystem...</div><span id="ctl00_ThumbnailUrl" class="date" content="https://codeproject.global.ssl.fastly.net/script/Articles/Images/reference100x80.png"></span>			

                    </div>
                    
					
					

					

					
					

					
					
					
					

						
					

					

						
						<div id="contentdiv" class="text">
						



<h2>Introduction</h2><p>
NuGet is a free, open source package management system for .NET and consists out of a few client tools (NuGet Command Line and NuGet Visual Studio Extension) and the official NuGet Gallery hosted at <a href="http://www.nuget.org/" target="_blank">http://www.nuget.org/</a>. Combined, these tools and the gallery form the NuGet project, governed by <a href="http://www.outercurve.org/" target="_blank">Outercurve Foundation</a> and part of the ASP.NET Open Source Gallery. Although fully open source, Microsoft has extensively contributed to the development of the NuGet project.</p><p>First introduced in 2010, NuGet has been around for a few years now and many people and organizations are beginning to realize that NuGet presents a great opportunity to improve and automate parts of their development processes. Whether you work on open source projects or in an enterprise environment, NuGet is here to stay, but you have a way bigger NuGet ecosystem at your disposal today.</p><h2>Background</h2><p>
	This article talks about the NuGet ecosystem. If you are new to NuGet or need practical guidance on how to use NuGet, then I highly recommend you to read through the <a href="http://docs.nuget.org" target="_blank">NuGet documentation</a> or buy the book <a href="http://bit.ly/ProNuGet" target="_blank">Pro NuGet</a> for a full reference, tips and tricks.</p><h2>Training Materials</h2><p>
	Using a new tool or technology usually comes with a learning curve. Luckily for you, NuGet has no steap learning curve it all! In fact, anyone can <a href="http://www.youtube.com/watch?feature=player_embedded&v=PboPfoptU2c" target="_blank">get started consuming packages in no time</a>. Authoring packages however, and especially authoring good packages, as well as embracing NuGet in your automated build and deployment processes requires some research in order to get things right. </p><p>The following pointers should help you get the maximum out of NuGet:</p><ul><li>Official NuGet Documentation site: <a href="http://docs.nuget.org/" target="_blank">http://docs.nuget.org/</a></li><li>NuGet Blog: <a href="http://blog.nuget.org/">http://blog.nuget.org/</a></li><li>NuGet team on Twitter: <a href="http://twitter.com/nuget" target="_blank">@nuget</a></li><li>JabbR chat: <a href="https://jabbr.net/#rooms/nuget">https://jabbr.net/#rooms/nuget</a></li><li>MSDN article: <a href="http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/magazine/jj851071.aspx" target="_blank">Top 10 NuGet (anti-)patterns</a></li><li>Book: <a href="http://bit.ly/ProNuGet" target="_blank">Apress Pro NuGet</a></li><li>My blog also has a few NuGet related posts: <a href="http://www.xavierdecoster.com/tagged/NuGet" target="_blank">http://www.xavierdecoster.com/tagged/NuGet</a></li></ul><h2>The NuGet ecosystem</h2><p>Because the NuGet project is open source under a permissive <a href="http://choosealicense.com/licenses/apache/" target="_blank">Apache v2</a> license, other projects can leverage NuGet and companies can build support for it in their products. All of them extend the NuGet ecosystem to what it is today, containing:</p><ul><li><a href="#outercurve">Outercurve Foundation NuGet Project</a></li><li><a href="#microsoft">NuGet-based tools by Microsoft</a></li><li><a href="#npe">NuGet Package Explorer</a></li><li><a href="#myget">MyGet (NuGet-as-a-Service)</a></li><li><a href="#chocolatey">Chocolatey</a> </li><li><a href="#octopusdeploy">OctopusDeploy</a></li><li><a href="#deploymentmanager">RedGate Deployment Manager</a> </li><li><a href="#symbolsource">SymbolSource</a></li><li><a href="#proget">ProGet (Inedo)</a> </li><li><a href="#coapp">CoApp</a> </li><li><a href="#boxstarter">BoxStarter</a> </li><li><a href="#otheride">SharpDevelop NuGet plug-in</a></li><li><a href="#otheride">Xamarin NuGet plug-in</a> </li><li><a href="#build">TeamCity support for NuGet</a></li><li><a href="#build">Artifactory support for NuGet</a></li><li><a href="#build">Nexus support for NuGet</a> </li><li><a href="#other">Glimpse Plug-ins</a></li><li><a href="#otheride">ReSharper Plug-ins </a></li><li><a href="#other" target="_blank">Orchard</a> </li><li><a href="#other">NuGetMustHaves</a> </li><li><a href="#other">NuGetFeed</a></li><li><a href="#other">NuGetLatest</a></li><li><a href="#other">NuGet server in Java</a></li><li><a href="#other">NuGet Fight</a></li><li><a href="#other">NuGit</a></li></ul><p>
</p><hr><h3><a name="outercurve" title="outercurve" class="anchor" id="outercurve">Outercurve Foundation</a></h3><p>The sources for the Outercurve NuGet clients can be found on <a href="http://nuget.codeplex.com/" target="_blank">Codeplex</a>, while the NuGet Gallery sources  are available on <a href="https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery" target="_blank">GitHub</a>. </p><p>The Outercurve tools for NuGet include:</p><ul><li><div>NuGet Core project</div></li><ul><li><div>Download: <a href="https://nuget.codeplex.com/" target="_blank">sources</a> (Codeplex) or <a href="http://www.nuget.org/packages/Nuget.Core/" target="_blank">NuGet package</a></div></li><li><div>License: Apache v2</div></li><li><div>Most NuGet client tools are based on the cross-platform <code>NuGet.Core</code> project. If you want to build your own NuGet client, you're best bet is to fetch the NuGet.Core project's <a href="https://nuget.codeplex.com/" target="_blank">sources from Codeplex</a>, or to run the following command in the NuGet Package Manager Console:</div></li></ul></ul><blockquote><blockquote><div class='pre-lang' id='premain904060'><div></div><div class='pre-action-link'><span id='copycode904060' class='copy-code' data-index='904060' style='visibility:hidden'>Copy Code</span></div></div>
<pre id='pre904060' style='margin-top:0;' data-allowShrink='True' data-collapse='False'>
Install-Package NuGet.Core</pre></blockquote></blockquote><ul><li>NuGet Command Line tool (which is a wrapper around NuGet.Core)</li><ul><li>Download: <a title="Download the latest version of the NuGet command line tool." href="https://nuget.org/nuget.exe">nuget.exe</a></li><li>Reference: <a href="http://docs.nuget.org/reference/command-line-reference">http://docs.nuget.org/reference/command-line-reference</a></li><li>License: Apache v2</li></ul><li>NuGet Server project</li><ul><li>Download: <a href="http://www.nuget.org/packages/NuGet.Server">http://www.nuget.org/packages/NuGet.Server</a></li><li>License: Apache v2</li><li>Sources: <a href="http://nuget.codeplex.com/">http://nuget.codeplex.com/</a></li></ul><li>NuGet Concierge</li><ul><li>License: Apache v2 </li><li>Sources: <a href="https://github.com/NuGet/Concierge" target="_blank">https://github.com/NuGet/Concierge</a> </li><li>A package recommendation service: upload a packages.config file and NuGet Concierge will recommend you packages you may find useful.</li><li>URL: <a href="http://concierge.nuget.org/" target="_blank">http://concierge.nuget.org/</a> </li><li>More info: <a href="http://blog.nuget.org/20130816/introducung-nuget-concierge.html" target="_blank">http://blog.nuget.org/20130816/introducung-nuget-concierge.html</a> </li></ul><li>Official NuGet Gallery at <a href="http://www.nuget.org">http://www.nuget.org</a> </li><ul><li>Statistics: <a href="http://www.nuget.org/stats">http://www.nuget.org/stats</a></li><li>Availability: <a href="http://status.nuget.org">http://status.nuget.org</a></li><li>License: Apache v2</li><li>Sources: <a href="https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery">https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery</a></li></ul></ul><p>If you want to setup your own NuGet server using the tools provided by the Outercurve Foundation, you can do so using any of the following methods:</p><ul><li>To create a basic NuGet server and point it to a local folder or network share, create a new ASP.NET application and run the following command in the Package Manager Console:</li></ul><blockquote><div class='pre-lang' id='premain809071'><div></div><div class='pre-action-link'><span id='copycode809071' class='copy-code' data-index='809071' style='visibility:hidden'>Copy Code</span></div></div>
<pre id='pre809071' style='margin-top:0;' data-allowShrink='True' data-collapse='False'>
Install-Package NuGet.Server</pre></blockquote><ul><ul><li>Benefits: </li><ul><li>requires minimal infrastructure (IIS and some diskspace)</li><li>requires .NET Framework 4.0</li></ul><li>Drawbacks:</li><ul><li>non-indexed storage (slower as repository-size increases)</li><li>single API key for entire server</li><li>no fine-grained security</li><li>single NuGet feed per NuGet.Server application</li></ul></ul><li>To set up your own NuGet Gallery, fetch the sources from GitHub and follow the instructions at <a href="https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery">https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery</a>.</li><ul><li>Benefits:</li><ul><li>indexed storage (faster querying)</li><li>basic user system (authentication, API-key per user, manage own packages, emails)</li><li>supports SSL</li></ul><li>Drawbacks:</li><ul><li>requires proper infrastructure (IIS, SqlServer)</li><li>requires .NET Framework 4.5 (I consider this a drawback due to the fact that .NET 4.5 is an in-place upgrade)</li><li>requires you to fetch the sources, compile everything and configure quite a lot in source code and configuration files (and repeat this step if you want to upgrade to a newer version)</li><li>there's a <a href="https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetOperations" target="_blank">NuGet Gallery Operations Toolkit</a>, but it's not designed nor intended to work with every NuGetGallery installation</li></ul></ul></ul><p>
</p><hr><h3><a name="microsoft" title="microsoft" class="anchor" id="microsoft">Microsoft</a></h3><p>The following NuGet clients are being shipped as part of Microsoft products and available as extensions on each product's extension gallery:</p><ul><li>WebMatrix 3 NuGetPackageManager extension: </li><ul><li>Download: <a href="http://extensions.webmatrix.com/packages/NuGetPackageManager/">http://extensions.webmatrix.com/packages/NuGetPackageManager/</a></li></ul><li>NuGet-based Microsoft Package Manager for Visual Studio 2010 and 2012</li><ul><li>Download: <a href="http://visualstudiogallery.msdn.microsoft.com/27077b70-9dad-4c64-adcf-c7cf6bc9970c">http://visualstudiogallery.msdn.microsoft.com/27077b70-9dad-4c64-adcf-c7cf6bc9970c</a></li><li>Reference:</li><ul><li>Using the <a href="http://docs.nuget.org/docs/start-here/managing-nuget-packages-using-the-dialog" target="_blank">Manage NuGet Packages dialog</a></li><li>Using the <a href="http://docs.nuget.org/docs/start-here/using-the-package-manager-console" target="_blank">Package Manager Console</a></li></ul><li>License: <a href="http://visualstudiogallery.msdn.microsoft.com/site/27077b70-9dad-4c64-adcf-c7cf6bc9970c/eula?licenseType=None" target="_blank">Microsoft Software License (custom)</a></li></ul><li>NuGet-based Microsoft Package Manager for Visual Studio 2013</li><ul><li>Download: <a href="http://visualstudiogallery.msdn.microsoft.com/4ec1526c-4a8c-4a84-b702-b21a8f5293ca" target="_blank">http://visualstudiogallery.msdn.microsoft.com/4ec1526c-4a8c-4a84-b702-b21a8f5293ca</a></li><li>Reference:</li><ul><li>Using the <a href="http://docs.nuget.org/docs/start-here/managing-nuget-packages-using-the-dialog" target="_blank">Manage NuGet Packages dialog</a></li><li>Using the <a href="http://docs.nuget.org/docs/start-here/using-the-package-manager-console" target="_blank">Package Manager Console</a></li></ul><li>License: <a href="http://visualstudiogallery.msdn.microsoft.com/site/4ec1526c-4a8c-4a84-b702-b21a8f5293ca/eula?licenseType=None" target="_blank">Microsoft Software License (custom)</a></li></ul></ul><p>
</p><hr><h3><a name="npe" title="npe" class="anchor" id="npe">NuGet Package Explorer</a></h3><p>One of the developers of the core NuGet team at Microsoft created a great graphical tool to work with NuGet packages. It allows you to very easily create, publish, download and inspect NuGet packages and their metadata.</p><ul><li>Click-once (desktop) application: <a href="http://npe.codeplex.com">http://npe.codeplex.com</a></li><li>Windows 8 app: <a href="http://apps.microsoft.com/windows/en-us/app/nuget-package-explorer/3148c5ae-7307-454b-9eca-359fff93ea19/m/ROW">http://apps.microsoft.com/windows/en-us/app/nuget-package-explorer/3148c5ae-7307-454b-9eca-359fff93ea19/m/ROW</a></li></ul><p>
</p><hr><h3><a name="myget" title="myget" class="anchor" id="myget">MyGet (or NuGet-as-a-Service)</a></h3><p>MyGet is a NuGet server that allows you to create and host your own NuGet feeds. It is hosted on Windows Azure and has a freemium offering, meaning you can use it for free (within the constrains of <a href="https://www.myget.org/plans" target="_blank">the free plan</a>) or subscribe to one of the paying plans if you require more resources or features. More info at <a href="https://www.myget.org">https://www.myget.org</a>. </p><ul><li>Availability and history: <a href="http://status.myget.org">http://status.myget.org</a>. </li><li>Documentation: <a href="http://docs.myget.org">http://docs.myget.org</a>. </li><li>Twitter: <a href="https://twitter.com/mygetteam">https://twitter.com/mygetteam</a></li><li>JabbR: <a href="https://jabbr.net/#/rooms/myget">https://jabbr.net/#/rooms/myget</a></li><li>Provides:</li><ul><li>requires no infrastructure</li><li>allows you to get started in a few clicks and focus on the packages instead of the server</li><li>fully compatible with all NuGet client tools</li><li>free software updates (including support for to the latest NuGet version)</li><li>free for open source projects (meeting criteria and within allowed quota)</li><li>publish and promote your feed in the public gallery</li><li>supports <a href="http://nugetext.org/" target="_blank">NuGet Feed Discovery</a> and <a href="http://psd.myget.org/" target="_blank">Package Source Discovery</a></li><li>extended feed functionality</li><ul><li>SSL-by-default</li><li>feed visibility (public, readonly or private)</li><li>activity streams</li><li>strict SemVer validation for packages being pushed</li><li>upload packages directly in the browser </li><li>add packages from another feed (upstream package source)</li><li>upstream package source presets for nuget.org (including webmatrix and other curated feeds), chocolatey, teamcity, etc</li><li>filter upstream package sources</li><li>mirror upstream package sources</li><li>package promotion to an upstream package source</li><li>(automatic or manual) package mirroring</li><li>RSS</li><li>package retention rules</li><li>download entire feeds as ZIP archives for backup purposes</li><li>download packages from the web (without the need for nuget client tools)</li><li>integration with symbolsource (shared credentials and feed/repository security settings)</li><li>multiple endpoints, including the v1-compatible endpoint (e.g. you can use the feed as a custom Orchard Gallery feed)  </li></ul><li>granular security</li><ul><li>API key per user</li><li>user-roles on feeds (owner, co-owner, contributor, reader)</li><li>user management (enterprise plan)</li><li>quota management (enterprise plan)</li><li>web site authentication using on-premise ADFS (enterprise plan)</li><li>web site authentication using prefered identity providers: Live ID, Google, GitHub, StackOverflow, etc (enterprise plan)</li></ul><li>build services</li><ul><li>creates the NuGet and symbols packages for you</li><li>customizable automatic-versioning and assembly version patching</li><li>auto-trigger builds for CodePlex, BitBucket or GitHub commits</li><li>support for many unit testing frameworks</li><li>support for many SDKs (including windows phone)</li><li>build failure notifications through email and downloadable build logs</li></ul><li>custom logo and domain name (enterprise plan)</li></ul></ul><p>
</p><hr><h3><a name="chocolatey" title="chocolatey" class="anchor" id="chocolatey">Chocolatey</a> </h3><p><a href="http://www.chocolatey.org" target="_blank">Chocolatey.org</a> is a system-level package manager for Windows based on NuGet, allowing you to search and install software components on your system, even unattended. Looks very promising and definitely something to keep an eye on!</p><ul><li>Documentation: <a href="https://github.com/chocolatey/chocolatey/wiki">https://github.com/chocolatey/chocolatey/wiki</a></li><li>Reference: <a href="https://github.com/chocolatey/chocolatey/wiki/CommandsReference">https://github.com/chocolatey/chocolatey/wiki/CommandsReference</a></li><li>Twitter: <a href="http://twitter.com/chocolateynuget">http://twitter.com/chocolateynuget</a></li><li>Forums: <a href="http://groups.google.com/group/chocolatey">http://groups.google.com/group/chocolatey</a></li><li><a href="http://groups.google.com/group/chocolatey"></a>License: Apache v2 </li><li>Provides:</li><ul><li>Unattended software installations</li><li>Installation of multiple packages with a single command</li><li>Easy to use command line tool</li><li>Supports any NuGet package source (feeds and file shares)</li><li>Has a GUI as well: <a href="http://chocolatey.org/packages/ChocolateyGUI">http://chocolatey.org/packages/ChocolateyGUI</a></li><li>Integration with:</li><ul><li>Web Platform Installer</li><li>Windows Features</li><li>Ruby Gems</li><li>CygWin</li><li>Python</li></ul></ul></ul><p>
</p><hr><h3><a name="octopusdeploy" title="octopusdeploy" class="anchor" id="octopusdeploy">OctopusDeploy</a></h3><p><a href="http://octopusdeploy.com/" target="_blank">OctopusDeploy</a> is a convention-based automated deployment solution using NuGet as a protocol. You can use the Community edition for free (limited to 1 project) or <a href="http://octopusdeploy.com/purchase" target="_blank">buy</a> one of the paying editions.</p><ul><li>Documentation: <a href="http://octopusdeploy.com/documentation">http://octopusdeploy.com/documentation</a></li><li>Blog: <a href="http://octopusdeploy.com/blog">http://octopusdeploy.com/blog</a></li><li>Twitter: <a href="https://twitter.com/OctopusDeploy">https://twitter.com/OctopusDeploy</a></li><li>Provides:</li><ul><li>Deployment dashboard</li><li>Scalability through lightweight service agents (<em>tentacles</em>)</li><li>Deployment promotion between environments</li><li>Support for PowerShell scripts</li><li>Support for manual interventions</li><li>Support for XML configuration transforms and variables</li><li>Support for Windows Azure web and worker roles</li><li>Support for (S)FTP</li><li>Has a TeamCity plug-in</li><li>Has a Command Line (octo.exe)</li><li>Has a REST API</li><li>Fine-grained user permissions</li><li>Retention policies</li><li>Automation of common tasks for ASP.NET deployments (IIS configuration) and Windows Services</li></ul></ul><hr><h3><a name="#deploymentmanager" title="#deploymentmanager" class="anchor" id="#deploymentmanager">Deployment Manager (RedGate)</a> </h3><p>RedGate's <a href="http://www.red-gate.com/delivery/deployment-manager/" target="_blank">Deployment Manager</a> is a custom fork of the OctopusDeploy project. History separates shortly after v1.0 of OctopusDeploy, as explained in <a href="http://octopusdeploy.com/support/red-gate" target="_blank">this post</a>. </p><p>More info:  <a href="http://www.red-gate.com/delivery/deployment-manager/">http://www.red-gate.com/delivery/deployment-manager/</a></p><p>
</p><hr><h3><a name="symbolsource" title="symbolsource" class="anchor" id="symbolsource">SymbolSource</a></h3><p><a href="http://www.symbolsource.org">SymbolSource</a> is a hosted symbolserver that integrates with NuGet and is configurable in Visual Studio, allowing you to debug NuGet packages by downloading the symbols and sources on-demand.</p><ul><li>Documentation: <a href="http://www.symbolsource.org/Public/Wiki/Index">http://www.symbolsource.org/Public/Wiki/Index</a></li><li>Blog: <a href="http://www.symbolsource.org/Public/Blog">http://www.symbolsource.org/Public/Blog</a></li><li>Forums: <a href="http://groups.google.com/group/symbolsource">http://groups.google.com/group/symbolsource</a></li><li>Provides:</li><ul><li>Consumes and provides NuGet symbols packages</li><li>Consumes and provides OpenWrap packages</li><li>Hosts symbols (PDB files) and sources (C#, VB.NET, C++)</li><li>Symbol server and source server compatible with Visual Studio</li><li>Flexible security for public and private content</li><li>Integration with MyGet.org (shared credentials and feed/repository security settings)</li><li>Integration with NuGet.org (default symbols repository)</li></ul></ul><h3><hr><a name="coapp" title="coapp" class="anchor" id="coapp">CoApp</a></h3><p>The <a href="http://coapp.org/" target="_blank">CoApp</a> project <em>originally</em> aimed to create a vibrant Open Source ecosystem on Windows by providing the technologies needed to build a complete community-driven Package Management System, along with tools to enable developers to take advantage of features of the Windows platform. </p><p>The project has <a href="http://coapp.org/news/2013-03-27-The-Long-Awaited-post.html" target="_blank">pivoted</a> to <em>mesh</em> with the NuGet project and the collaborative result is visible in NuGet 2.5 where <a href="http://docs.nuget.org/docs/release-notes/nuget-2.5#Support_for_Native_projects" target="_blank">support for native packages</a> was first introduced. The CoApp project is still building <a href="http://coapp.org/pages/releases.html" target="_blank">additional tools</a> to enhance C/C++ support in NuGet. </p><p>
</p><ul><li>Documentation: <a href="http://coapp.org/pages/reference.html">http://coapp.org/pages/reference.html</a></li><li><a href="http://coapp.org/pages/reference.html"></a>Twitter: <a href="https://twitter.com/#!/coapp" target="_blank">@CoApp</a> </li><li>Sources: <a href="https://github.com/coapp/" target="_blank">https://github.com/coapp/</a>  </li><li>License: Apache v2</li></ul>
<p>
</p><hr><h3><a name="proget" title="proget" class="anchor" id="proget">ProGet (Inedo)</a></h3><p>
<a href="http://inedo.com/proget/overview" target="_blank">ProGet</a> is an on-premise NuGet server with a freemium model that also provides integration with the Inedo BuildMaster product.</p><ul><li>Documentation: <a href="http://inedo.com/support/documentation/table-of-contents">http://inedo.com/support/documentation/table-of-contents</a></li><li>Twitter: <a href="http://twitter.com/inedo">http://twitter.com/inedo</a></li><li>Provides:</li><ul><li>Compatibility with all NuGet client tools</li><li>Custom proget.exe client tool</li><li>Connectors to other NuGet feeds</li><li>Connector filters</li><li>Support for multiple feeds</li><li>Support for private feeds</li><li>License filtering</li><li>Download feeds and packages</li><li>LDAP authentication to the ProGet web application</li><li>Upload packages to the ProGet web application</li><li>integrated symbols and source server</li><li>SDK and API</li><li>Supports OData</li><li>Supports NuGet Feed Discovery and NuSpec Extensions</li></ul></ul><p>
</p><hr><h3><a name="boxstarter" title="boxstarter" class="anchor" id="boxstarter">BoxStarter</a> </h3><p>
</p><p><a href="http://boxstarter.codeplex.com/" target="_blank">BoxStarter</a> is another cool project leveraging NuGet and Chocolatey to quickly set up development environments. </p><p>
</p><ul><li>Documentation: <a href="http://boxstarter.codeplex.com/documentation">http://boxstarter.codeplex.com/documentation</a></li><li>Sources: <a href="http://boxstarter.codeplex.com/">http://boxstarter.codeplex.com/</a></li><li>License: Apache v2 </li></ul><p>
</p><p>
</p><hr><p>
</p><h3><a name="otheride" title="otheride" class="anchor" id="otheride">Other IDE support for NuGet</a></h3>
<h4>SharpDevelop </h4><p>SharpDevelop was amongst the first IDEs other than Visual Studio to support NuGet.</p><p>More info: <a href="http://community.sharpdevelop.net/blogs/mattward/archive/2011/01/23/NuGetSupportInSharpDevelop.aspx">http://community.sharpdevelop.net/blogs/mattward/archive/2011/01/23/NuGetSupportInSharpDevelop.aspx</a></p><h4>Xamarin and MonoDevelop</h4><p>Xamarin Studio and MonoDevelop also have a NuGet extension, built on top of a custom build of the NuGet.Core.dll and a custom build of Microsoft's XML Document Transformation (XDT) library.</p><p>More info: <a href="https://github.com/mrward/monodevelop-nuget-addin">https://github.com/mrward/monodevelop-nuget-addin</a></p><h4>ReSharper Plug-ins </h4><p>As of v8.0 of <a href="http://www.jetbrains.com/resharper/" target="_blank">ReSharper</a>,  the built-in extension manager allows you to fetch ReSharper plug-in packages from a custom NuGet Gallery hosted at <a href="https://resharper-plugins.jetbrains.com/">https://resharper-plugins.jetbrains.com</a>. </p>
<p>
</p><hr><p>
</p><h3><a name="build" title="build" class="anchor" id="build">Build Tools and Repository Managers</a></h3><h4>
TeamCity</h4><p>TeamCity has a few build steps specifically designed to deal with NuGet package consumption, creation and publication. In addition, it also comes with a built-in NuGet feed collecting all packages produced in your build artifacts.</p><p>More info: <a href="http://blogs.jetbrains.com/dotnet/2011/08/native-nuget-support-in-teamcity/">http://blogs.jetbrains.com/dotnet/2011/08/native-nuget-support-in-teamcity/</a></p><h4>Artifactory</h4><p>Artifactory is a repository manager with built-in support for various artifacts, including NuGet packages.</p><p>More info: <a href="http://www.jfrog.com/confluence/display/RTF/NuGet+Repositories">http://www.jfrog.com/confluence/display/RTF/NuGet+Repositories</a></p><h4>Sonatype Nexus</h4><p>Nexus is another repository manager with built-in support for NuGet and they even provide a "<a href="http://blog.sonatype.com/people/2012/02/what-is-nuget-for-java-developers/" target="_blank">What is NuGet for Java Developers</a>" on their blog.</p><p>More info: <a href="http://books.sonatype.com/nexus-book/reference/nuget.html">http://books.sonatype.com/nexus-book/reference/nuget.html</a></p><p>
</p><hr><p>
</p><h3><a name="other" title="other" class="anchor" id="other">Other NuGet-based utilities</a></h3><p>There are quite a few other tools and utilities building further on top of NuGet. Here's a list of what I've found interesting:  </p><ul><li><a href="http://getglimpse.com/Packages" target="_blank">Glimpse Extensions</a> (plug-ins are packages)  </li><li><a href="http://nugetmusthaves.com">NuGetMustHaves.com</a> </li><li><a href="http://nugetfeed.org/" target="_blank">NuGetFeed</a> (build a list of favorite packages) </li><li><a href="http://www.orchardproject.net/" target="_blank">Orchard</a> (CMS modules are fetched from a v1 NuGet feed hosted in the <a href="http://gallery.orchardproject.net/" target="_blank">Orchard Gallery</a>)  </li><li><a href="http://blog.jonnyzzz.name/2012/03/nuget-server-in-pure-java.html" target="_blank">Java implementation of NuGet Server</a></li><li><a href="http://www.nugetfight.com" target="_blank">NuGet Fight!</a></li><li><a href="http://nugit.org" target="_blank">NuGit</a></li><li><a href="https://twitter.com/NuGetLatest" target="_blank">NuGetLatest</a> (Twitter bot tweeting new package publications)</li></ul><p>
</p><hr><p>
</p><p>It is great to see how NuGet adoption is growing, especially when people come up with innovative ideas that facilitate our work even further. And if any of you has a way to improve the NuGet tools, whether the Outercurve, Microsoft or any other NuGet-based product, then please tell them about your ideas. Report defects, log feature requests, provide feedback, write documentation or submit a pull request and experience eternal gratitude from an entire community :-)</p><h2>History </h2><ul><li>August 19th, 2013 - Added NuGet Concierge project </li><li>August 1st, 2013 - Updated Coapp project description </li><li>July 30, 2013 - First published<br>
</li></ul>

    <div class="description">
        Xavier Decoster is a .NET/ALM consultant living in Belgium and co-founder of MyGet.org. He co-authored the book Pro NuGet and is a Microsoft Extended Experts Team member in Belgium.<br />
<br />
He hates development friction and does not respect time zones. In order to make other developers aware of how frictionless development can and should be, he tries to share his experiences and insights by contributing back to the Community as a speaker, as an author, as a blogger, and through various open source projects.<br />
<br />
His blog can be found at http://www.xavierdecoster.com and you can follow him on Twitter.

Xavier Decoster is a .NET/ALM consultant living in Belgium and co-founder of MyGet.org. He co-authored the book Pro NuGet and is a Microsoft Extended Experts Team member in Belgium.

He hates development friction and does not respect time zones. In order to make other developers aware of how frictionless development can and should be, he tries to share his experiences and insights by contributing back to the Community as a speaker, as an author, as a blogger, and through various open source projects.

His blog can be found at http://www.xavierdecoster.com and you can follow him on Twitter.

                        <div id="ctl00_DescriptionSpot" class="summary">Windows Toast Notification in C++</div><span id="ctl00_ThumbnailUrl" class="date" content="https://www.codeproject.com/KB/Articles/5286393/Thumbnail.png"></span>			

                    </div>
                    
					
					

					

					
					<div id="ctl00_Abstract" class="abstract">In this article, you will learn the steps to use Windows Toast Notification library in C++.</div>

					
					
					
					

						
					

					

						
						<div id="contentdiv" class="text">
						



<ul class="download">
	<li><a href="/KB/Articles/5286393/TestToast8.zip">Download TestToast8.zip - 162.2 KB</a></li></ul>

<h2>Introduction</h2>

<p>Windows Toast is a small window appearing bottom-right of the screen, is a common method whereby an application notifies its user an event of interest has occurred, for instance, an video encoding session has completed. Compared to <code>MesssageBox()</code> which shows a child modal window of your application is like a shove in your user's face especially when your application is currently not in the foreground. In this regard, Windows Toast is less intrusive. But to understand and use its complex API correctly is not an easy task.</p>

<p><a href="https://github.com/mohabouje/WinToast">WinToast</a> by Mohammed Boujemaoui is an excellent Windows Toast Notification library that does a good job of hiding the complexity of showing a toast on Windows and most importantly, ease of use.</p>

<p>To get started, copy the <em>wintoastlib.h</em> and <em>wintoastlib.cpp</em> from the <a href="https://github.com/mohabouje/WinToast">WinToast</a> repo to your project and include its header and use the namespace, <code>WinToastLib</code>.</p>

<div class='pre-lang' id='premain681014'><div>C++</div><div class='pre-action-link'><span id='copycode681014' class='copy-code' data-index='681014' style='visibility:hidden'>Copy Code</span></div></div>
<pre id='pre681014' style='margin-top:0;' class='lang-cplusplus' data-language='C++' data-allowShrink='True' data-collapse='False'>
<span class="code-keyword">#include</span><span class="code-preprocessor"> <span class="code-string">"</span><span class="code-string">wintoastlib.h"</span>
</span>
<span class="code-keyword">using</span> <span class="code-keyword">namespace</span> WinToastLib;</pre>

<p>The second step is to implement the <code>IWinToastHandler</code> interface's <code>toastActivated</code>, <code>toastDismissed</code> and <code>toastFailed</code> virtual methods. The <code>actionIndex</code> parameter of <code>toastActivated</code> method returns the zero-based index of the button clicked.</p>

<div class='pre-lang' id='premain859393'><div>C++</div><div class='pre-action-link'><span id='copycode859393' class='copy-code' data-index='859393' style='visibility:hidden'>Copy Code</span></div></div>
<pre id='pre859393' style='margin-top:0;' class='lang-cplusplus' data-language='C++' data-allowShrink='True' data-collapse='False'>
<span class="code-keyword">class</span> WinToastHandler : <span class="code-keyword">public</span> WinToastLib::IWinToastHandler
{
public:
    WinToastHandler(CDialogEx* pDialog) : m_pDialog(pDialog) {}
    <span class="code-comment">// Public interfaces
</span>    <span class="code-keyword">void</span> toastActivated() <span class="code-keyword">const</span> <span class="code-keyword">override</span> {}
    <span class="code-keyword">void</span> toastActivated(<span class="code-keyword">int</span> actionIndex) <span class="code-keyword">const</span> <span class="code-keyword">override</span> {
        <span class="code-keyword">wchar_t</span> buf[<span class="code-digit">250</span>];
        swprintf_s(buf, L<span class="code-string">"</span><span class="code-string">Button clicked: %d"</span>, actionIndex);
        m_pDialog-<span class="code-keyword">></span>MessageBox(buf, L<span class="code-string">"</span><span class="code-string">info"</span>, MB_OK);
    }
    <span class="code-keyword">void</span> toastDismissed(WinToastDismissalReason state) <span class="code-keyword">const</span> <span class="code-keyword">override</span> {}
    <span class="code-keyword">void</span> toastFailed() <span class="code-keyword">const</span> <span class="code-keyword">override</span> {}
private:
    CDialogEx* m_pDialog;
};</pre>

<p>Then add the concrete <code>WinToastHandler</code> as a member of your class.</p>

<div class='pre-lang' id='premain526854'><div>C++</div><div class='pre-action-link'><span id='copycode526854' class='copy-code' data-index='526854' style='visibility:hidden'>Copy Code</span></div></div>
<pre id='pre526854' style='margin-top:0;' class='lang-cplusplus' data-language='C++' data-allowShrink='True' data-collapse='False'>
WinToastHandler m_WinToastHandler;</pre>

<p>The third step is to configure <code>AppUserModelId</code> (AUMI) which consists of <code>CompanyName</code>, <code>ProductName</code>, <code>SubProductName</code> and <code>VersionInformation</code>. For UWP application, this step can be skipped as the UWP will fill up the information provided by your MSIX installer. For desktop applications like pure Win32 or MFC, this step is essential else the toast notification will fail to work.</p>

<div class='pre-lang' id='premain242846'><div>C++</div><div class='pre-action-link'><span id='copycode242846' class='copy-code' data-index='242846' style='visibility:hidden'>Copy Code</span></div></div>
<pre id='pre242846' style='margin-top:0;' class='lang-cplusplus' data-language='C++' data-allowShrink='True' data-collapse='False'>
WinToast::WinToastError error;
WinToast::instance()-<span class="code-keyword">></span>setAppName(L<span class="code-string">"</span><span class="code-string">TestToastExample"</span>);
<span class="code-keyword">const</span> <span class="code-keyword">auto</span> aumi = WinToast::configureAUMI
                  (L<span class="code-string">"</span><span class="code-string">company"</span>, L<span class="code-string">"</span><span class="code-string">wintoast"</span>, L<span class="code-string">"</span><span class="code-string">wintoastexample"</span>, L<span class="code-string">"</span><span class="code-string">20201012"</span>);
WinToast::instance()-<span class="code-keyword">></span>setAppUserModelId(aumi);

<span class="code-keyword">if</span> (!WinToast::instance()-<span class="code-keyword">></span>initialize(&error)) {
    <span class="code-keyword">wchar_t</span> buf[<span class="code-digit">250</span>];
    swprintf_s(buf, L<span class="code-string">"</span><span class="code-string">Failed to initialize WinToast :%d"</span>, error);
    MessageBox(buf, L<span class="code-string">"</span><span class="code-string">Error"</span>);
}</pre>

<p>Your toast can consist of an image or a number of text lines based on the <code>WinToastTemplateType enum</code> passed to <code>WinToastTemplate</code> constructor. In case you are wondering what hero image is, hero image is the big image that appears at the top of the toast.</p>

<div class='pre-lang' id='premain923147'><div>C++</div><div class='pre-action-link'><span id='copycode923147' class='copy-code' data-index='923147' style='visibility:hidden'>Copy Code</span></div></div>
<pre id='pre923147' style='margin-top:0;' class='lang-cplusplus' data-language='C++' data-allowShrink='True' data-collapse='False'>
<span class="code-keyword">enum</span> WinToastTemplateType 
{
    ImageAndText01,
    ImageAndText02,
    ImageAndText03,
    ImageAndText04,
    Text01,
    Text02,
    Text03,
    Text04,
    HeroImageAndImageAndText01,
    HeroImageAndImageAndText02,
    HeroImageAndImageAndText03,
    HeroImageAndImageAndText04,
    HeroImageAndText01,
    HeroImageAndText02,
    HeroImageAndText03,
    HeroImageAndText04,
};</pre>

<p>The last step is to show the toast to your user. We chose to show 1 image and 2 lines of text with <code>ImageAndText02</code>. With Windows 10 Anniversary Update, we have the option of adding a hero image that appears on the top or inlined by calling the constructor with <code>HeroImageAndImageAndText02</code> and <code>setHeroImagePath()</code> with <code>inlineImage</code> set to <code>true</code> or <code>false</code>. <code>setImagePath()</code>'s second parameter can be set to <code>CropHint::Circle</code> to make the picture cropped in circle. This is only available with Windows 10 Anniversary Update. On older unsupported Windows 7/8/10, the picture is still displayed in a square. Two buttons, <code>Yes</code> and <code>No</code> are added through <code>addAction()</code>.</p>

<div class='pre-lang' id='premain945879'><div>C++</div><div class='pre-action-link'><span id='copycode945879' class='copy-code' data-index='945879' style='visibility:hidden'>Copy Code</span></div></div>
<pre id='pre945879' style='margin-top:0;' class='lang-cplusplus' data-language='C++' data-allowShrink='True' data-collapse='False'>
WinToastTemplate templ;
<span class="code-keyword">if</span> (WinToast::isWin10AnniversaryOrHigher())
{
    templ = WinToastTemplate(WinToastTemplate::HeroImageAndImageAndText02);
    <span class="code-keyword">bool</span> inlineImage = <span class="code-keyword">false</span>;
    templ.setHeroImagePath(L<span class="code-string">"</span><span class="code-string">C:\\Users\\u\\Pictures\\hero.jpg"</span>, 
        inlineImage);
}
<span class="code-keyword">else</span>
{
    templ = WinToastTemplate(WinToastTemplate::ImageAndText02);
}
templ.setImagePath(
    L<span class="code-string">"</span><span class="code-string">C:\\Users\\u\\Pictures\\pretty_gal.jpg"</span>, 
    WinToastTemplate::CropHint::Circle);

templ.setTextField(L<span class="code-string">"</span><span class="code-string">My First Toast"</span>, WinToastTemplate::FirstLine);
templ.setTextField(L<span class="code-string">"</span><span class="code-string">Say Hello?"</span>, WinToastTemplate::SecondLine);

templ.addAction(L<span class="code-string">"</span><span class="code-string">Yes"</span>);
templ.addAction(L<span class="code-string">"</span><span class="code-string">No"</span>);

<span class="code-comment">// Read the additional options section in the article
</span>templ.setDuration(WinToastTemplate::Duration::Short);
templ.setAudioOption(WinToastTemplate::AudioOption::Default);
templ.setAudioPath(WinToastTemplate::AudioSystemFile::Call1);

<span class="code-keyword">if</span> (WinToast::instance()-<span class="code-keyword">></span>showToast(templ, &m_WinToastHandler) == -<span class="code-digit">1L</span>)
{
    MessageBox(L<span class="code-string">"</span><span class="code-string">Could not launch your toast notification!"</span>, L<span class="code-string">"</span><span class="code-string">Error"</span>);
}</pre>

<p>This is the screenshot of the toast notification. Be sure to change the image path and hero image path in the sample code to valid images on your system, else the toast will display a generic icon.</p>

<p><img alt="toast screenshot" src="/KB/Articles/5286393/toast2.png" style="width: 356px; height: 142px"></p>

<p>This is the toast notification with a circle cropped image.</p>

<p><img alt="toast screenshot" src="/KB/Articles/5286393/toast_circle.png" style="width: 358px; height: 144px"></p>

<p>This is the toast notification with a top hero image. Why my hero image is not a picture of a superhero but scenery?! Actually, I am not aware of the reason Microsoft named the top image, "hero", just like why the toast notification is called "toast". The latter could be due to the similarity to the toast popping up in the toaster when toasted.</p>

<p><img alt="toast screenshot with top hero image" src="/KB/Articles/5286393/hero.png" style="height: 329px"></p>

<p>This is the toast notification with a big inlined image in the middle.</p>

<p><img alt="toast screenshot with a big inlined image in the middle" src="/KB/Articles/5286393/inline_image.png" style="height: 325px"></p>

<h2 id="additional_options">Additional Options</h2>

<ul>
	<li><strong>Attribution text:</strong> you can add/remove the attribution text, by default is empty. Use <code>WinToastTemplate::setAttributionText</code> to modify it.</li>	<li><strong>Duration:</strong> The amount of time the toast should display. This attribute can have one of the following values:
	<ul>
		<li><em>System:</em> infinite display time until dismissed.</li>		<li><em>Short:</em> default system short time configuration.</li>		<li><em>Long:</em> default system long time configuration.</li>	</ul>
	</li>	<li><strong>Audio Properties:</strong> you can modify the different behaviors of the sound:
	<ul>
		<li><em>Default:</em> plays the audio file just one time.</li>		<li><em>Silent:</em> turn off the sound.</li>		<li><em>Loop:</em> plays the given sound in a loop during the toast existence.</li>	</ul>
	</li></ul>

<p>WinToast allows the modification of the default audio file. Add the given file in to your projects resources (must be <em>ms-appx://</em> or <em>ms-appdata://</em> path) and define it by calling: <code>WinToastTemplate::setAudioPath</code>.</p>

<p><strong>By default, WinToast checks if your systems support the features, ignoring the not supported ones.</strong></p>

<h2 id="fix_mem_leak">Memory Leak Fix</h2>

<p>When the article was first released in November 2020, its readers discovered memory leaks on Visual Studio. Using <a href="https://www.deleaker.com/">Deleaker</a>, I found a <code>HSTRING</code> leak and callback function token leaks. I fixed the former and for the latter, I keep adding the tokens in <code>_buffer</code> map member because there is no good time to release those tokens. It silences the Visual Studio memory leak detection but the ongoing token accumulation is detrimental to a long running application. The token is used to remove the callback as a subscriber of change notifications when notifications are no longer needed. The crux of the problem is I cannot release the token while on callback due to its memory/resource still being in use. I contemplated using a worker thread to monitor the <code>_buffer</code> but it brings other synchronization and object lifetime problems. Windows Toast Notification is based on COM which has its own threading apartment detail to take care of. The worker thread approach is complex to implement and error-prone. In the callback, it is safe to delete the previous object (that holds the tokens) and marks the current object for next deletion. So I chose this simple approach over the worker thread.</p>

<p>After the fix, the task manager showed the memory of private working set and commit size increased for the first few toast notifications and stabilized afterwards. I have merged my fix with the upstream to do a pull request. Now waiting for original developer, Mohammed Boujemaoui to merge my PR. There is a breaking change in <code>showToast()</code>: handler type is changed from <code>IWinToastHandler</code> raw pointer to <code>IWinToastHandler</code> smart pointer, so update your code accordingly from</p>

<div class='pre-lang' id='premain336966'><div>C++</div><div class='pre-action-link'><span id='copycode336966' class='copy-code' data-index='336966' style='visibility:hidden'>Copy Code</span></div></div>
<pre id='pre336966' style='margin-top:0;' class='lang-cplusplus' data-language='C++' data-allowShrink='True' data-collapse='False'>
<span class="code-keyword">if</span> (WinToast::instance()-<span class="code-keyword">></span>showToast(templ, &m_WinToastHandler) == -<span class="code-digit">1L</span>)
{...}</pre>

<p>to</p>

<div class='pre-lang' id='premain980480'><div>C++</div><div class='pre-action-link'><span id='copycode980480' class='copy-code' data-index='980480' style='visibility:hidden'>Copy Code</span></div></div>
<pre id='pre980480' style='margin-top:0;' class='lang-cplusplus' data-language='C++' data-allowShrink='True' data-collapse='False'>
<span class="code-sdkkeyword">std::shared_ptr</span><span class="code-keyword"><</span>IWinToastHandler<span class="code-keyword">></span> handler(<span class="code-keyword">new</span> WinToastHandler(<span class="code-keyword">this</span>));
<span class="code-keyword">if</span> (WinToast::instance()-<span class="code-keyword">></span>showToast(templ, handler) == -<span class="code-digit">1L</span>)
{...}</pre>

	<li>15<sup>th</sup> February, 2022: Fixed the memory leaks permanently. Read <a href="#fix_mem_leak">this section</a> for information.</li>	<li>4<sup>th</sup> December, 2021: Uploaded new demo which copies the images to the output directory during post-build event.</li>	<li>28<sup>th</sup> January, 2021: Added image.zip for those who want to recreate the toast presented in this article. Remember to update the image path in the example code correctly.</li>	<li>8<sup>th</sup> December, 2020: Added <a href="#additional_options">Additional Options section</a></li>	<li>22<sup>th</sup> November, 2020: Fixed memory leaks and added hero image and circle cropped image features</li>	<li>16<sup>th</sup> November, 2020: First release</li></ul>

<td colspan="2">When i press the button "Show Toast" there is no reaction. No MessageBox and no Toast.<br />
<br />
I modiefied the Code around the Messagebox like this:<br />
<div class='pre-lang' id='premain891907'><div>C++</div><div class='pre-action-link'><span id='copycode891907' class='copy-code' data-index='891907' style='visibility:hidden'>Copy Code</span></div></div>
<pre id='pre891907' style='margin-top:0;' class='lang-cplusplus' data-language='C++' data-allowShrink='True' data-collapse='False'>
WinToast::WinToastError error;
INT64 tst = WinToast::instance()-<span class="code-keyword">></span>showToast(templ, &m_WinToastHandler, &error);
<span class="code-keyword">if</span> ( tst == -<span class="code-digit">1L</span>)
{
	MessageBox(L<span class="code-string">"</span><span class="code-string">Could not launch your toast notification!"</span>, L<span class="code-string">"</span><span class="code-string">Error"</span>);
}</pre><br />
and found that i get this result<br />
<br />
<div class='pre-lang' id='premain885073'><div> </div><div class='pre-action-link'><span id='copycode885073' class='copy-code' data-index='885073' style='visibility:hidden'>Copy Code</span></div></div>
<pre id='pre885073' style='margin-top:0;' data-language='text' data-allowShrink='True' data-collapse='False'>
error	NoError (0)
tst	    22144290</pre><br />
Something is going wrong here.<br />
<br />
With the source from the original WinToast source there are many changes to todo, and it seems<br />
that this line makes problems for me:<br />
<br />
<div class='pre-lang' id='premain847163'><div>C++</div><div class='pre-action-link'><span id='copycode847163' class='copy-code' data-index='847163' style='visibility:hidden'>Copy Code</span></div></div>
<pre id='pre847163' style='margin-top:0;' class='lang-cplusplus' data-language='C++' data-allowShrink='True' data-collapse='False'>
HRESULT hr = notificationManager-<span class="code-keyword">></span>GetTemplateContent(ToastTemplateType(toast.type()), &xmlDocument);</pre><br />
The result here is E_INVALIDARG.<br />
<br />
At the End the lib makes something different than the used source here and the MessageBox with the Message "Could not launch your toast notification!" is displayed.<br />
<br />
It seems that the used WinToast source here is outdated and should be replaced.<br />
<br />
That does not solve my Problem, but shows a MessageBox.<br />
<br />
The Original Code does not Support the method isWin10AnniversaryOrHigher() and some other code.<br />
This method is called successfully for me when I incorporate it.<br />
<br />
Other programs show notifications, and i would like to know why this is not working here.<br /></td>

<br />
You should not use the demo code here with the original source because the assumption about who releases the memory of m_WinToastHandler is different now: in this source, the caller of showToast() is responsible while the original source does it for you. When you pass stack-allocated m_WinToastHandler to the original showToast() which will free it, a crash may happen.<br /><br /></td>

The demo does not work or the code copied to your application does not work? There are some pointers below to help you troubleshoot.<br />

<ul>
<li>The <code>IWinToastHandler</code> derived object has to be alive (meaning in scope) when the toast is shown.</li><li>Is <code>CoInitialize()</code> called?</li><li>Is there any error MessageBox shown?</li><li>Is the image path points to a valid image?</li><li>I believe this toast cannot work in a windows service which is in Session 0.</li></ul>
<br />
